channel.title: Anabasis (The March of the Ten Thousand) — Modern Simple on Dual Classics
channel.description: Recent content in Anabasis (The March of the Ten Thousand) — Modern Simple on Dual Classics

item.title: Chapter 1: Cyrus and the King
item.description: Cyrus wants to be king.

item.title: Chapter 2: March to Celaenae
item.description: Friends join Cyrus. The army grows.

item.title: Chapter 3: The Soldiers' Revolt
item.description: The soldiers refuse to march and Clearchus must choose between Cyrus and his men.

item.title: Chapter 4: Through Syria to the Gates
item.description: Cyrus marches through Syria and faces fortified passes on his way to confront the king.

item.title: Chapter 5: Through the Desert
item.description: The army crosses the Arabian desert, hunting wild animals and struggling to find food.

item.title: Chapter 6: The Traitor Orontas
item.description: A Persian noble tries to betray Cyrus but is caught and put on trial.

item.title: Chapter 7: The King's Army Approaches
item.description: The army prepares for battle as the king’s forces draw near.

item.title: Chapter 8: The Battle Begins
item.description: The king’s army approaches and the Greek soldiers prepare for battle.

item.title: Chapter 9: The Death of Cyrus
item.description: The story of Cyrus’s death and remembrance of his noble character.

item.title: Chapter 10: The March Continues
item.description: The army releases prisoners to move faster and marches with better discipline.

item.title: Chapter 11: After Cyrus (Book II, Chapter 1)
item.description: The Greek leaders decide their next steps after Cyrus’s death and face demands from the king.

item.title: Chapter 12: The Alliance and Night March (Book II, Chapter 2)
item.description: The Greeks join forces with Ariaeus and begin their dangerous march through enemy territory.

item.title: Chapter 13: The King's Truce (Book II, Chapter 3)
item.description: The Greeks negotiate a truce with the king and cross difficult terrain while searching for food.

item.title: Chapter 14: Waiting and Worrying (Book II, Chapter 4)
item.description: The Greeks grow uneasy as they wait with Ariaeus while Persian visitors ignore them.

item.title: Chapter 15: Through the Desert to the Gates (Book II, Chapter 5)
item.description: The army struggles through the Arabian desert, losing many animals to starvation.

item.title: Chapter 16: The Betrayal and Death of Clearchus (Book II, Chapter 6)
item.description: The Greek commanders are betrayed, captured, and executed by the king.

item.title: Chapter 17: Xenophon's Dream (Book III, Chapter 1)
item.description: Xenophon, a thoughtful Athenian, has a prophetic dream as the Greeks face their darkest hour.

item.title: Chapter 18: The New Leaders Rise (Book III, Chapter 2)
item.description: After the betrayal, new leaders emerge to rally the Greek soldiers with speeches of courage and honor.

item.title: Chapter 19: Mithridates the Spy (Book III, Chapter 3)
item.description: A Persian named Mithridates pretends to help but is revealed as a spy for the king.

item.title: Chapter 20: Ancient Cities and Tissaphernes Returns (Book III, Chapter 4)
item.description: The Greeks discover mysterious abandoned cities and face Tissaphernes once again.

item.title: Chapter 21: Burning Villages and a Clever Plan (Book III, Chapter 5)
item.description: Tissaphernes burns villages while the Greeks devise an ingenious river crossing plan.

item.title: Chapter 22: Through the Carduchian Mountains (Book III, Chapter 6)
item.description: The Greeks struggle through steep passes while Carduchians attack from the heights.

item.title: Chapter 23: The Snowstorm (Book III, Chapter 7)
item.description: A deadly snowstorm hits until Xenophon rallies the army with hope and practical steps.

item.title: Chapter 24: River Crossing and New Hope (Book III, Chapter 8)
item.description: The army builds rafts to cross a wide river and finds renewed hope.

item.title: Chapter 25: Night Climb into Carduchia (Book IV, Chapter 1)
item.description: Cheirisophus leads light troops and Xenophon the heavy soldiers into steep Carduchian passes.

item.title: Chapter 26: Strong Lines on the Summit (Book IV, Chapter 2)
item.description: Xenophon and Cheirisophus steady the army; the Carduchians fall back.

item.title: Chapter 27: Book IV, Chapter 3
item.description: Into Armenia; distances, rivers, and a cautious treaty with Tiribazus.

item.title: Chapter 28: A Surprise Charge and an Empty City
item.description: Mithridates attacks; the Greeks counter and reach ruined Larissa.

item.title: Chapter 29: The Ruins of Mespila
item.description: Pyramids, towering walls at Mespila, and skirmishing with Tissaphernes.

item.title: Chapter 30: Wounds and Rest in the Villages
item.description: Wounded and weary, the Greeks find food, wine, and three days of rest—then fight off Tissaphernes again.

item.title: Chapter 31: Race to the Ridge
item.description: The Persians try to block a narrow ridge; the Greeks sprint for the high ground.

item.title: Chapter 32: Hard Hills and a Flank
item.description: Steep climbs wear the Greeks down, until light troops strike from above.

item.title: Chapter 33: Hunger and a Plan
item.description: Short on food, the army debates ships home and safer foraging.

item.title: Chapter 34: Sea at Last!
item.description: The army reaches the Black Sea and shouts with joy.

item.title: Chapter 35: Sea, Games, and Plans
item.description: They reach the sea at Trapezus, celebrate, and plan for ships.

item.title: Chapter 36: Raids in the Hills
item.description: Short on food, they raid the Drilae; unity keeps them alive.

item.title: Chapter 37: Split and Rescue
item.description: The army splits; Xenophon rushes to help trapped Arcadians.

item.title: Chapter 38: Strange Honey
item.description: The reunited Greeks find villages—and dizzying, strange honey.

item.title: Chapter 39: Cotyora and Gifts
item.description: At Cotyora, Paphlagonian envoys visit; feasts, dances, and peace.

item.title: Chapter 40: Sinope and a Choice
item.description: They reach Sinope; Anaxibius’s promise; the army debates one leader.

item.title: Chapter 41: A Leader Chosen
item.description: Xenophon declines sole command; Cheirisophus is chosen.

item.title: Chapter 42: Heraclea and Restraint
item.description: At Heraclea, the army leaves hungry but avoids harming fellow Greeks.

item.title: Chapter 43: Calpe’s Temptation
item.description: Calpe’s fine harbor tempts them to settle; they vote to march on.

item.title: Chapter 44: Calpe Raids and Ambushes
item.description: Restless at Calpe, they raid inland; tribes ambush from the forests.

item.title: Chapter 45: A City Dream Set Aside
item.description: Calpe’s promise of a colony fades; Sparta’s anger feared.

item.title: Chapter 46: Farewell to Cheirisophus
item.description: Cheirisophus falls ill and dies; the march goes on.

item.title: Chapter 47: Discipline Restored
item.description: After Cheirisophus dies, disorder rises until Xenophon restores order.

item.title: Chapter 48: Byzantium’s Shut Gates
item.description: Hungry at Byzantium, they seek peace and finally receive food.

item.title: Chapter 49: A Broken Promise
item.description: Anaxibius promises pay if they leave the sea—then refuses.

item.title: Chapter 50: Hold Fast With Honor
item.description: After Anaxibius’s broken promise, the army resists mutiny and holds together.

item.title: Chapter 51: Cleander’s Promise
item.description: A new Spartan, Cleander, proves fair and gives hope.

item.title: Chapter 52: Leaving Byzantium
item.description: They prepare to leave Byzantium, united and closer to home.

item.title: Chapter 53: Into Asia with Thibron
item.description: Leaving Byzantium, they join Thibron’s campaign with promise of pay.

item.title: Chapter 54: Discipline Before Thibron
item.description: Xenophon restores discipline as they prepare to march with Thibron.

item.title: Chapter 55: Allies of Sparta
item.description: Marching for Thibron against the Persian satraps, their name inspires fear.

item.title: Chapter 56: Hesitant Command, Steady Courage
item.description: Thibron hesitates; the Greeks fight bravely and the Persians avoid battle.

item.title: Chapter 57: Dercylidas Takes Command
item.description: Sparta replaces Thibron with Dercylidas; energy and respect return.

item.title: Chapter 58: Xenophon Stays On
item.description: Xenophon considers going home; the soldiers beg him to stay, and he agrees.

item.title: Chapter 59: Fame and Loyalty
item.description: With Dercylidas, their fame spreads; Xenophon stays out of loyalty.

item.title: Chapter 60: Cities and Unity
item.description: Welcomed or feared, they keep together, a family far from Greece.

item.title: Chapter 61: Nearing Pergamon
item.description: They approach Pergamon; the long march nears its end.

item.title: Chapter 62: Gifts at Pergamon
item.description: In Pergamon, Gongylus aids them; Xenophon keeps the peace.

item.title: Chapter 63: Called Once More
item.description: Spartans call the Ten Thousand to fight Persians again; they agree.

item.title: Chapter 64: Torn Between Home and Honor
item.description: Xenophon longs for home, yet feels pride and duty to the army.

item.title: Chapter 65: The Ten Thousand’s Name
item.description: Smaller now, they still carry the Ten Thousand’s proud name.

item.title: Chapter 66: March’s End, Story Begins
item.description: The march ends; Xenophon preserves their story for all time.

item.title: Glossary
item.description:
🧑‍🤝‍🧑 People (Personas)

Xenophon ZEN-oh-fon / Jenofonte JEH-no-fon-te

English
A Greek general and writer. He became one of the leaders of the Ten Thousand and later wrote their story.
Español
Un general y escritor griego. Se convirtió en uno de los jefes de los Diez Mil y luego escribió su historia.

Cheirisophus KYE-ri-SOF-us / Queirisófo KYE-ri-SOF-o

English
A Spartan general who often shared command with Xenophon. Loyal but sometimes unlucky.
Español
Un general espartano que compartió el mando con Jenofonte. Leal pero a veces con mala suerte.

Proxenus PROK-sen-us / Próxeno PROK-se-no

English
A Greek general from Boeotia, friend of Xenophon, killed in Tissaphernes’ trap.
Español
Un general griego de Beocia, amigo de Jenofonte, asesinado en la trampa de Tisasfernes.

Clearchus KLEE-ar-kus / Clearco KLEE-ar-co

English
A tough Spartan general who led the army early on. He was captured and executed by Persians after the treachery.
Español
Un duro general espartano que dirigió al ejército al inicio. Fue capturado y ejecutado por los persas tras la traición.

Menon MEH-non / Menón Me-NON

English
A Thessalian general, ambitious and selfish, also killed after Tissaphernes’ betrayal.
Español
Un general tesalio, ambicioso y egoísta, también muerto tras la traición de Tisasfernes.

Socrates SO-kra-tees / Sócrates SO-cra-tes

English
Famous philosopher of Athens, teacher of Xenophon. He advised Xenophon not to join Cyrus, but Xenophon went anyway.
Español
Famoso filósofo de Atenas, maestro de Jenofonte. Le aconsejó no unirse a Ciro, pero Jenofonte fue de todos modos.

Cyrus the Younger SY-rus / Ciro el Joven SEE-ro el HO-ben

English
Persian prince who hired the Ten Thousand. Killed at Cunaxa.
Español
Príncipe persa que contrató a los Diez Mil. Murió en Cunaxa.

Artaxerxes Ar-tak-ZURK-sees / Artajerjes Ar-ta-HER-hes

English
The Great King of Persia, enemy of Cyrus and the Ten Thousand.
Español
El Gran Rey de Persia, enemigo de Ciro y de los Diez Mil.

Tissaphernes TIS-ah-FER-nees / Tisasfernes TIS-ah-FER-nes

English
Persian satrap who betrayed the Greek generals.
Español
Sátrapa persa que traicionó a los generales griegos.

Orontas oh-RON-tas / Orontas o-RON-tas

English
Persian noble and rival of Cyrus.
Español
Noble persa y rival de Ciro.

Anaxibius Ah-NAK-sib-ee-us / Anaxibio Ah-NAK-sib-ee-o

English
Spartan admiral who promised pay but deceived the soldiers.
Español
Almirante espartano que prometió paga pero engañó a los soldados.

Thibron THY-bron / Tíbron TEE-bron

English
Spartan general who used the Ten Thousand in Asia.
Español
General espartano que usó a los Diez Mil en Asia.

Dercylidas Der-sih-LY-das / Dercílidas Der-see-LEE-das

English
Spartan general who replaced Thibron and treated the Greeks more fairly.
Español
General espartano que reemplazó a Tíbron y trató a los griegos con más justicia.

🏛️ Greek Ethnic Groups (Grupos griegos)

Spartans SPAR-tans / Espartanos Es-par-TA-nos

English
Soldiers from Sparta, disciplined and feared warriors.
Español
Soldados de Esparta, guerreros disciplinados y temidos.

Athenians Ath-EE-nee-ans / Atenienses A-te-NYEN-ses

English
Soldiers from Athens, famous for democracy and seafaring. Xenophon was Athenian.
Español
Soldados de Atenas, famosos por la democracia y la navegación. Jenofonte era ateniense.

Arcadians ar-KAY-dee-ans / Arcadios Ar-KAH-dios

English
The largest Greek group in the army, from central Greece. Fierce fighters but often unruly.
Español
El grupo griego más grande del ejército, de la Grecia central. Guerreros feroces pero a menudo indisciplinados.

Achaeans ah-KEE-ans / Aqueos Ah-KEH-os

English
Greeks from the Peloponnesus. They often marched with the Arcadians.
Español
Griegos del Peloponeso. A menudo marchaban con los arcadios.

Thessalians Thes-SAY-lee-ans / Tesalios Teh-SAH-lee-os

English
From Thessaly, known for their cavalry. Menon was Thessalian.
Español
De Tesalia, conocidos por su caballería. Menón era tesalio.

Boeotians Bee-OH-she-ans / Beocios Be-OH-sios

English
From Boeotia, north of Athens. Proxenus was Boeotian.
Español
De Beocia, al norte de Atenas. Próxeno era beocio.

Cretans KREE-tans / Cretenses Cre-TEN-ses

English
From the island of Crete, famous as skilled archers.
Español
De la isla de Creta, famosos por ser arqueros expertos.

Rhodians ROH-dee-ans / Rodios ROH-dios

English
From the island of Rhodes, known for their powerful slingers.
Español
De la isla de Rodas, conocidos por sus honderos poderosos.

🌍 Places (Lugares)

Babylon BAB-ih-lon / Babilonia Ba-bi-LO-nia

English
Near where Cyrus fought Artaxerxes at Cunaxa.
Español
Cerca de donde Ciro luchó contra Artajerjes en Cunaxa.

Cunaxa Koo-NAK-sa / Cunaxa Koo-NAK-sa

English
Battle site where Cyrus died.
Español
Lugar de la batalla donde Ciro murió.

Trapezus TRAP-eh-zoos / Trapezunte TRAP-eh-zun-te

English
Greek city on the Black Sea where the soldiers cried “The sea! The sea!”
Español
Ciudad griega en el mar Negro donde los soldados gritaron “¡El mar! ¡El mar!”

Sinope SIN-oh-pee / Sinope SEE-no-pe

English
Major Greek port on the Black Sea.
Español
Importante puerto griego en el mar Negro.

Heraclea Heh-RAK-lee-ah / Heraclea Heh-RAK-lee-ah

English
Greek city fearful of the Ten Thousand.
Español
Ciudad griega temerosa de los Diez Mil.

Calpe KAL-pee / Calpe KAL-pe

English
Coastal site where the Greeks considered founding a colony.
Español
Lugar costero donde los griegos pensaron fundar una colonia.

Pergamon PER-ga-mon / Pérgamo PER-ga-mo

English
Greek city where the long march ended.
Español
Ciudad griega donde terminó la larga marcha.

⚔️ Armies & Tribes (Ejércitos y Tribus)

The Ten Thousand / Los Diez Mil

English
The Greek mercenary army that fought its way home.
Español
El ejército de mercenarios griegos que luchó para regresar a casa.

Paphlagonians Paf-la-GO-nee-ans / Paflagonios Paf-la-GO-nee-os

English
Neighbors who made peace with the Greeks.
Español
Vecinos que hicieron la paz con los griegos.

Thracians THRAY-shuns / Tracios TRAH-see-os

English
Fierce tribes with horsemen who attacked the Greeks.
Español
Tribus feroces con jinetes que atacaron a los griegos.

Drilae DRI-lie / Drileos DRI-leh-os

English
Mountain tribes resisting the army.
Español
Tribus de montaña que resistieron al ejército.

Carduchians Car-DOO-kee-ans / Carducos Car-DOO-cos

English
Highland tribes of fierce warriors who attacked from the mountains.
Español
Tribus de las montañas, guerreros feroces que atacaban desde lo alto.

📏 Old Terms (Términos antiguos)

Satrap SAY-trap / Sátrapa SÁ-tra-pa

English
Persian provincial governor.
Español
Gobernador de provincia persa.

Parasang PAIR-ah-sang / Parasanga PA-ra-san-ga

English
Persian distance measure ≈ 3.5 miles / 5.6 km.
Español
Medida persa de distancia ≈ 5,6 km.

Hoplite HOP-lite / Hoplita Hop-LEE-ta

English
Greek heavily armed foot soldier.
Español
Soldado griego con armadura pesada.

Peltast PEL-tast / Peltasta Pel-TAS-ta

English
Greek light soldier with javelins and a small shield.
Español
Soldado griego ligero con jabalinas y escudo pequeño.

Slinger SLING-er / Hondista On-DEES-ta

English
Soldier who fought with a sling, throwing stones or lead bullets.
Español
Soldado que luchaba con honda, lanzando piedras o proyectiles de plomo.
